title: brand.yml Design
text:
Design exploration for brand.yml and shinytheme.





flowchart LR
    by{brand.yml}
    by-->quarto
    by-->bslib
    bslib-->R[Shiny for R]
    bslib-->rmd[R Markdown]
    by-->shinytheme
    shinytheme-->bs[bootstrap.min.css]
    shinytheme-->py[Shiny for Python]

title: brand.yml Structure
text:
brand.yml

1meta:
  # company stuff

2logo:
  icon:
  logo:

3color:
  # named colors

4theme:
  # semantic colors

5font:
  heading:
  body:
  monospace:

6typography:
  # basic rules

7options:
  # basic non-color theme settings

8variable:
  html: ~
  pdf: ~
  remarkjs: ~
  <format>: ~

format:
  html: ~
  pdf: ~
  <format>: ~


1

meta: Key identity information, name of the company, links to brand guidelines, etc.

2

logo: Files or links to the brand’s logo at various sizes.

3

color: Named colors in the brand’s color palette.

4

theme: Semantic colors, e.g. primary, secondary, success, warning, etc.

5

font: Font definitions for heading, body and monospace fonts.

6

typography: Font family, weight, style, color, and line height for key elements, e.g. headings at levels 1-6, body, blockquote, links, bold, italic, lists, etc.

7

options: Non-color related theme options, e.g. border radius, use of shadows or transparency, etc.

8

variable, format: Format-specific style variables and options. Style variables would be used by the various pre-processors and the format item could be merged into the quarto format frontmatter key.

title: brand.yml
text:
brand.yml

meta:
  # company stuff

logo:
  small:
  medium:
  large:

color:
  # named colors

theme:
  # semantic colors

font:
  heading:
  body:
  monospace:

typography:
  # basic rules

variable:
  html: ~
  pdf: ~
  remarkjs: ~
  <format>: ~

format:
  html: ~
  pdf: ~
  <format>: ~


[meta][meta.qmd]

Key identity information, name of the company, links to brand guidelines, etc.

[logo][logo.qmd]

Files or links to the brand’s logo at various sizes.

[color][color-and-theme.qmd]

Named colors in the brand’s color palette.

[theme][color-and-theme.qmd]

Semantic colors, e.g. primary, secondary, success, warning, etc. Also dynamic colors.

[font][font.qmd]

Font definitions for heading, body and monospace fonts.

[typography][typography.qmd]

Font family, weight, style, color, and line height for key elements, e.g. headings at levels 1-6, body, blockquote, links, bold, italic, lists, etc.

[variable, format][variable-and-format.qmd]

Format-specific style variables and options. Style variables would be used by the various pre-processors and the format item could be merged into the quarto format frontmatter key.

title: brand.yml
text:
Open Questions

Assets
It’s unlikely that a brand.yml will be completely self-contained. In many cases, users will want to include static assets, including:

logo files
images and icons
stylesheets
LaTeX includes
custom fonts



Light/dark themes
Should light and dark be high up in the tree or on each field?

Some fields won’t have both
Easier to see the full dark or full light theme when higher up
In most cases dark mode is light mode with a small number of tweaks



brand.yml (high-level light/dark)

logo:
  light:
    small:
    large:
  dark:
    small:
    large:



brand.yml (local light/dark)

logo:
  small:
    light:
    dark:
  large:
    light:
    dark:



Reusing fields
brand.yml authors will need to re-use fields in various areas. The most obvious of these are the interaction between named colors in the color section and semantic colors in the theme section.
For example, Home Depot defines orange as #F96302. The brand.yml author wants to use this specific color for as the primary accent color.

Sass-like variables
One option is to use Sass-like variables.


brand.yml

color:
  orange: "#F96302"

theme:
  primary: "$orange"

This option is very close to how the variables are used in scss files, but the brand.yml intends to support more formats than Sass and CSS outputs.
Additionally, $orange implies a top-level orange field, but is actually defined in color.orange.


Native YAML anchors and aliases
YAML has a native block re-use concept called anchors and aliases. It is not pretty and adds a lot of work for the end user.


brand.yml

color:
  orange: &orange "#F96302"

theme:
  primary: *orange

It doesn’t seem terrible in this small example, but it’s a lot of extra in larger brand definitions.
This does have the advantage of working with native constructs, and all YAML readers and validators should be able to read and validate this format.


Custom syntax
Another option is to use a custom syntax that any brand.yml consumer will have to implement. This syntax might look like this:


brand.yml

color:
  orange: "#F96302"

theme:
  primary: "{{ color['orange'] }}"

In this proposal, the brand.yml reader would:

Find fields that start and end with { }
Evaluate the syntax inside. color['orange'] is valid R, Python and JavaScript to access the "orange" item of the "color" list, dictionary or object1.

After processing, the brand.yml imported into R would be equivalent to the following:
list(
  color = list(
    orange = "#F96302"
  ),
  theme = list(
    primary = "#F96302"
  )
)

title: brand.yml
text:
Footnotes


Technically, the R version would need to be unnested one level. But importantly, this syntax wouldn’t feel out of place to users of our three favorite languages.↩︎

Key identity information, name of the company, links to brand guidelines, etc.

title: Walmart
text: Walmart Brand Guidelines

title: Walmart
text:
Colors



Walmart palette



Primary color palette

We are a blue brand with white & yellow. Walmart Blue is the primary color that should be applied across all communications, to uphold brand consistency.

For .com &/or digital platforms, use digital blue to accommodate readability & legibility needs.
White complements digital blue & is either a background color or a type color.
Spark Yellow should be used as an accent color. Note: For yellow headlines used online, please refer to the ADA compliance section below.





Hex
CMYK
PMS
Name




#0071DC
CMYK 100, 45, 0, 0
PMS 285 C
Walmart Blue


#FFFFFF
CMYK 0, 0, 0, 0
White



#FFC220
CMYK 0, 25, 100, 0
PMS 1235 C
Spark Yellow





Secondary color palette

Our secondary color palette is an extension of our primary colors & is used as backgrounds & texture for silhouetted product photography. Where primary colors applied to type fail in legibility & compliance, use Ozark Noir.




Hex
CMYK
Name




#F8E6A5
CMYK 3, 7, 42, 0
Yellow Tone


#8CD1FC
CMYK 39, 5, 0, 0
Blue Tone 1


#D3EFF8
CMYK 16, 0, 2, 0
Blue Tone 2


#FAFAFA
CMYK 1, 1, 1, 0
Off White


#041E42
CMYK 100, 88, 42, 51
Ozark Noir

title: Open Questions

Example yaml schema from Quarto

title: Open Questions
text:
Flat or tree structure?
Generally, I think we should prefer flat-structured YAML. But we may want to include tree-structured YAML under certain conditions. What are those rules of thumb?


flat.yml

name: Posit Software, PBC
name-full: Posit Software, PBC
name-short: Posit



tree-or-single.yml

name:
  full: Posit Software, PBC
  short: Posit

name: Posit Software, PBC

title: Metadata
text: meta provides a place to store metadata about the Company described in brand.yml. We should anticipate a few key pieces of information, but authors might want to include data we haven’t accounted for.

title: Metadata
text: meta provides a place to store metadata about the Company described in brand.yml. We should anticipate a few key pieces of information, but authors might want to include data we haven’t accounted for.

title: Metadata
text:
Example


brand.yml

meta:
  name: Posit
  link: https://posit.co



brand.yml

meta:
  name:
    full: Posit Software, PBC
    short: Posit
  link:
    home: https://posit.co
    guide: https://positpbc.atlassian.net/wiki/x/AQAgBQ
    mastodon: https://fosstodon.org/@Posit
    linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/posit-software/
    twitter: https://twitter.com/posit_pbc

title: Metadata
text:
Spec
- id: name
  description: The brand name.
  anyOf:
    - string
    - object:
        properties:
          full: 
            string:
              description: The full, official or legal name of the company or brand.
          short: 
            string:
              description: The short, informal, or common name of the company or brand.

- id: link
  description: >
    Important links for the brand, including social media links.
    If a single string, it is the brand's home page or website.
    Additional fields are allowed for internal use.
  anyOf:
    - string
    - object:
        properties:
          home: 
            string:
              description: The brand's home page or website.
          mastodon:
            string:
              description: The brand's Mastodon URL.
          github:
            string:
              description: The brand's GitHub URL.
          linkedin:
            string:
              description: The brand's LinkedIn URL.
          twitter:
            string:
              description: The brand's Twitter URL.
          facebook:
            string:
              description: The brand's Facebook URL.

title: Logo
text: Provide a logo and an icon for the company.

title: Logo
text: Provide a logo and an icon for the company.

title: Logo
text:
Example


brand.yml (simple)

logo: posit.png



brand.yml (full)

logo:
  small: posit-icon.png
  medium: posit.png
  large: posit.svg



brand.yml (light/dark)

logo:
  small: posit-icon.png
  medium: 
    light: posit.png
    dark: posit-reverese.png
  large: posit.svg

title: Slack
text:
Typography

Our brand fonts are Larsseit and Slack Circular. The following tables outline how best to use them.

Use Larsseit for headlines. …
Use Slack Circular for most other text, including paragraphs. …
Use Inter for Google Slides presentations
